thread.title_full: PIAA class expansion in multiple sports 'a really good thing' for District 11

title: PIAA class expansion in multiple sports 'a really good thing' for District 11
text:
The Parkland football team faced St. Joe's Prep in the 2014 Class AAAA state playoffs. (lehighvalleylive.com file photo) By Greg Joyce | For lehighvalleylive.com on October 07, 2015 9:29 PM, updated October 07, 2015 11:00 PM View/Post Comments 
The focus was on football, but the end result had a much wider scope. 
The PIAA Board of Directors voted Wednesday to expand classifications across multiple sports, setting up “a change across the state in the landscape of playoffs,” District 11 chairman and Whitehall AD Bob Hartman said. 
The vote passed 26-4 in favor of football moving from four to six classes. 
Then, the board voted 23-7 in favor of expanding basketball, baseball and softball to six classes; soccer and volleyball to four classes; field hockey to three classes; and lacrosse to two classes. 
“I think it’s a really good thing for our schools,” Hartman said Wednesday night. “It’s good for females, good for males, good for athletes in every season. … How do you do it for just football and not other sports? That’s shortsighted." 
RELATED : PIAA Board of Directors vote in favor of expansion for football and more 
The class expansion will be implemented for the 2016-17 season. 
"I think it was inevitable," Easton football coach Steve Shiffert said shortly after the decision. "The powers that be wanted Pennsylvania to be on par with other states with our number of high schools. It's going to give a lot more kids opportunities to play in state playoffs." 
One of the arguments against the expansion was fear of watering down championships, but Hartman doesn’t believe that will be an issue for the people it affects the most. 
“The team who wins a AA championship isn’t upset they won because they didn’t win AAA,” Hartman said. “It’s a championship. They’re excited about it. There’s more opportunities for kids to play in meaningful championship games. 
“Kids don’t say it’s bad. Maybe people in the stands think it’s watering things down, but it tends to be an adult argument, not a kid argument. 
“I just don’t see how it can’t be good for schools in District 11. There are tons of benefits, really.” 
Sports that combine team and individual tournaments, such as wrestling, swimming, golf, track and cross country, were not included in Wednesday’s vote. Bigger challenges exist in determining how that would play out, Hartman said, if the sports’ steering committees were even interested in doing so. 
The wrestling steering committee was not interested in going to three classes, Hartman said. 
What lies ahead now is a sorting-out process, with the next step being to collect enrollment numbers for schools to see where they line up in the new system. Schools will then have until Dec. 15 to decide if they want to move up in class size. 
If the vote for non-football sports had been pushed back, schools wouldn’t have had the opportunity to upgrade classes because the Board of Directors doesn’t meet until after the Dec. 15 deadline, Hartman said. 
By Dec. 17, districts will get a breakdown of where their schools classify in each sport. Drafts of brackets will come out in January and districts will go from there figuring out how it affects their playoff structure. 
For now, though, there is some closure to a move that has been a long time coming. 
“It’s probably a big day in Pennsylvania sports,” Hartman said. “Being a part of the change is neat to be a part of but it’s not without a lot of thought.”
